III. INVESTIGATION
1

Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth was sexually assaulted numerous times by an unknown
night shift staff member with the most recent time being, 5/16/24.
Youth reported this to their therapist in the past but was not
believed.
Investigation Interviews
On 05/31/2024 an in-person interview was held with Consumers
Rights Officer at Vista Maria. He was advised of the allegations.
He advised that Youth A was admitted and is currently
hospitalized. He further advised that Youth A has a history of
abuse and that she has made these allegations in the past against
staff and there were no findings.
On 06/03/2024 a telephone conversation took place with DHHS
Specialist. A date was confirmed to meet at Vista Maria for
interviews. DHHS specialist also advised that she had met with
Youth A at Kingswood Hospital. She reported Youth A was doing
well and on task for discharge by the weekend. The nursing staff
told DHHS Specialist that Youth A had not said anything about
being sexually abused. DHHS specialist said when she
interviewed Youth A Youth A stated she was being “touched” at
night by a staff at Vista Maria and indicated his name as “Staff 3”.
Youth A told her he was touching her breast and thighs. Youth A
further reported she had her clothes on and no other staff or youth
observed him coming into her room. Youth A also reported that
this is not the first case regarding allegations of sexual abuse with
the staff person and she is afraid of him and afraid to go back to
Vista Maria. She described the staff as a white male with facial
hair. Youth A further stated that male staff are not supposed to
come in the girl's bedrooms alone and that male staff do not
complete room checks on the midnight shift. She ended by
advising that the most recent time that the staff touched her was
two days before she came to the hospital.
2

All of the following interviews were conducted at Vista Maria on
06/05/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker unless otherwise
noted.
An interview was held with Consumer Rights Officer. He
advised that the only Caucasian staff that work midnights is Staff
1. The staff that worked the midnight shift two nights prior to
Youth A going to the hospital was Staff 1 and Staff 2. He further
advised that it is “best practice” for male staff to refrain from
completing bed checks at night and there is technically not a
policy that prohibits it. The Consumer Rights Officer confirmed
that Youth A went to the hospital on 5/19/24. He provided video
footage for review from 5/17/2024. A photo of Staff 1, the only
male staff working that night, was provided for review and he was
not found to have facial hair. DHHS Specialist also discussed and
implemented a safety plan with the agency that indicated agency
staff will not sexually abuse any of the minor children. Agency
staff understands it is their responsibility to always keep the minor
children safe and agree to report sexual abuse when it is
suspected. DHHS specialist advised that a second complaint had
come in and the perpetrator was identified as a “tall white man”.
Youth B was interviewed and confirmed that she sleeps in room 6
and Youth A sleeps in room 7. She stated that female staff
completes the room checks and denies that she has ever seen
any male staff going into Youth A’s room at night. She reported
that female staff often go into the room of Youth A at night to
make sure she uses the bathroom as she sometimes wets herself
at night. She has not seen any male staff going into Youth A’s
room at night. Youth B denied ever hearing Youth A make any
noises in her room, talk to any male staff during the night or
observed male staff coming out of Nevaeh's room. Youth B
denied being aware of any staff named “Staff 3” that works at the
agency.
Youth A was interviewed and reported that the alleged staff
person that assaulted her is a tall white male with a buzz cut, with
a beard but no mustache. She advised that he does not have any
visible tattoos or piercings. She reported not knowing his last
name. She denied that she said anything to staff about the
concerns because he told her that he would hurt staff at the
agency if she told anyone. Youth A was further able to confirm
that Staff 1 works midnights, but stated he never came into her
room. Youth A was adamant that it was Staff 3 who works
3

midnights at the agency and came into her room. She denied that
Staff 3 goes by any other name and that other youth at the agency
also call him by that name.
It was noted by the DHHS specialist, myself and the Foster Care
Worker who had joined the interview that Staff 1 does not fit the
description provided.
An interview was held with Foster Care Worker. She reported
Youth A has never reported any concern to her regarding staff
being inappropriate with her at the agency or any male staff
coming into her room. She advised Youth A has made similar
allegations in the past with no findings. She further advised Youth
A is diagnosed with Post Traumatic Stress Disorder and Major
Depressive Disorder. She struggles with hallucinations and
suicidal ideations/attempts. She receives IEP services for specific
learning disability. She is currently receiving Individual therapy
and psychiatric services
On 06/21/2024 a voicemail message was left for the Complaint
requesting a return call if there are additional concerns.
On 06/21/2024 a telephone interview was held with Staff 1.
DHHS specialist was also present on the conference call. Staff 1
reported that he has been working at Vista Maria for over 24
years. He reported working midnights and denied knowing any
staff by the name of Staff 3. He reported that Youth A never
disclosed to him or any other staff that any staff were
inappropriately touching her or coming into her room at night. He
explained he never observed any staff going into her room either.
Staff 1 disclosed the male staff do not complete room checks at
night due to the girls being asleep in their rooms. Female staff are
the only staff that complete the room checks on the midnight shift.
He indicated he has never gone into Youth A’s bedroom when he
worked midnights or any other shift.
On 06/21/2024 attempted phone calls were made to Staff 2 and
Therapist 1 without success. A message was left to return call to
DHHS specialist or myself. On 06/24/2024 a telephone
conversation was held with DHHS specialist. She advised that
she received two return calls but was unable to merge me into the
calls at the time. First call was from Therapist 1 who reported
Youth A has not disclosed to her in their therapy sessions being
sexually abused by any staff at Vista recently. She disclosed that
Youth A has been having hallucinations. She further confirmed
that there is no staff that she is aware of by the name of Staff 3.
4

The next call was from Staff 2. She confirmed that she works
midnights at Vista Maria. She disclosed there is no male staff by
the name of Staff 3 who works midnights. She reported that
Youth A has never said anything about a male staff touching her
inappropriately. She also denied that male staff complete room
checks during the midnight shift. DHHS specialist also advised
that she had spoke with law enforcement and confirmed that the
case has not been assigned yet, and it is unknown if the case will
be assigned at this time.
On 06/24/2024 a DHHS Disposition Meeting was held. DHHS
Specialist confirmed that there is no Vista Maria staff by the name
of Staff 3 on any shift. DHHS will provide final finding soon.
There are no preliminary findings of non-compliance with licensing
rules.
On 07/09/2024 a phone call was held with Therapist 1. She
denied that Youth A made any statements to her about a recent
sexual assault that occurred at Vista Maria involving a male staff
during therapy sessions.
Documents Reviewed
The staff and client interaction policy for Vista Maria was
reviewed. The policy documented that when making room
checks, respect the client's privacy. A male staff member should
never make visual checks of a residential client's bedroom or
bathroom area. Staff should not enter a client's bedroom without
advising additional staff of their whereabouts. Staff who enter a
client's room alone may be jeopardizing their personal safety and
security as well as the safety of others. Staff members should
never present themselves in a manner that could be construed as
flirtatious or sexual in nature to clients.
Video Reviewed
Video footage was received that included midnight coverage prior
to Youth A going to Kingswood. It was reviewed. A male staff was
not observed going into Youth A’s room during the midnight shift.
Female staff were observed doing the room checks on the
midnight shift.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance of licensing rule 4126 as there
was not evidence to support a rule violation. Staff interviews,
youth interviews and review of video footage did not support the
allegation that staff failed to provide supervision or acted
inappropriately with Youth A.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
5

Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following: (c)
Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care, safety, and
supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff person left cleaning supplies in the room of youth and the
youth drank them, resulting in the need to go to the hospital.
Investigation Interviews
All of the following interviews were conducted at Vista Maria on
06/05/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker unless otherwise
noted.
An interview was held with Consumer Rights Officer. He
advised that Youth A was originally taken to the hospital due to
reports that she had consumed cleaning supplies that had been
left in her room by staff. Consumer Rights Officer reported that
the agency had reviewed all video footage from the previous night
and staff was seen both entering and exiting with a cleaning
supply bottle. He further reported that the agency previously had
an issue with youth accessing cleaning solutions and using them
inappropriately, but the issue had been addressed and corrected
via the agencies corrective action plan.
Youth B was interviewed and confirmed that she sleeps in room 6
and Youth A sleeps in room 7. Youth B confirmed that cleaning
supplies at the agency are stored and locked in a closet. She
denied ever seeing a staff person leave cleaning supplies out for
youth to have access. She reported that staff will spray down
areas to be cleaned and then return the cleaning supplies to the
closet. She denied Youth A said anything to her about a staff
leaving cleaning supplies in her room. She added she does not
think Youth A drank any cleaning supplies as she often says
things for attention and believed this to be one of those
occurrences. She further added that Youth A was throwing up
because she was eating hot chips when she was not supposed to.
6

Supervisor 1 was interviewed and reported that she came to the
unit to do rounds between 6pm and 7pm. She stated Youth A was
in the bathroom and was throwing up. Youth A reported that she
had eaten fries and then stated that she did not want to say what
else happened. Supervisor 1 reported Youth A eventually told her
that she had drank cleaning solution that was yellow in color.
Supervisor 1 said that she noted Youth A’s throw up was clear.
She then reported that she contacted the nurse and poison control
and was advised to take Youth A to the Emergency Department
(ED). She was taken to Henry Ford Fairlane. Supervisor 1
reported that Youth A informed hospital staff the cleaning solution
was blue. Supervisor 1 noted the agency does not have any blue
cleaning supplies but did have yellow and pictures where taken
and sent to the hospital staff so they would be aware of any
possible type of cleaning supply. Supervisor 1 denied seeing any
cleaning supplies in the room of Youth A. Supervisor 1 reported
that it was important to note that Youth A reported drinking the
cleaning supplies in the morning between 6am and 7am after
midnight staff left it in her room but did not experience any
discomfort that resulted in her throwing up until about 6pm or 7pm.
Youth A was interviewed and reported that Staff 4 left cleaning
supplies on a table in her room during the midnight shift,
specifically around 6am. She reported the cleaning solution was
yellow and that she sprayed four sprays in her mouth at
approximately 7am. She recalled that the staff came back and
retrieved the cleaning supply right before she started throwing up
but could not recall who the staff person was. She denied that
she could be throwing up due to eating hot Cheetos that may have
irritated her stomach.
On 06/21/2024 a telephone interview was completed with Staff 4.
She denied leaving cleaning supplies in the room of Youth A or
any youth of the facility. She reported that she only sprays areas
of the room and never sets the cleaning supplies down or leaves
them in the room of youth.
On 06/21/2024 a telephone interview was held with Staff 1. He
denied knowledge of any cleaning supplies being left out in the
room of youth. He confirmed that all cleaning supplies are stored
and locked in a closet that cannot be accessed by youth.
On 06/21/2024 attempted phone calls were made to Staff 2 and
Therapist 1 without success. A message was left to return call to
DHHS specialist or myself.
7

On 06/24/2024 a telephone conversation was held with DHHS
specialist. She advised that she received two return calls, but was
unable to merge me into the calls at the time.
On 07/05/2024 attempted phone calls were again made to Staff 2
and Therapist 1 without success. A message was left to return
call.
On 07/09/2024 a telephone call was held with Therapist 1. She
denied knowledge of staff leaving cleaning supplies out in the
room of any of the youth and specifically not in the room of Youth
A.
Documents Reviewed
Vista Maria Standard Cleaning Policy was reviewed. It indicates
that scouring cleanser or acid cleaners are products used by staff
and custodians only and must be kept in the secured supply area.
Video Reviewed
Video footage was received that included midnight coverage prior
to Youth A going to Kingswood Hospital. It was reviewed and staff
could be seen going into the room of Youth A, however it could
not be clearly seen if staff exited the bedroom with or without
cleaning supplies in hand.
Analysis The agency was found to be in compliance with licensing rule
4109.1.C as there was no evidence to support that the agency
had violated the policy. Review of camera footage, interviews of
staff and interviews of youth did not result in evidence of rule non-
compliance. In addition, interview of Youth A resulted in
inconsistent report of the type and color of cleaning solution
ingested.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules.
